title: “Most Product Teams have no ROI” -ex Google, Bitly PM

rawLines.text: [Music]
you should listen to this episode
because the business expects something
from your team and if you don't know
what it is, you're in trouble. You're
trying to get that affirmative
commitment. You're trying to create
clarity. You want to sound smart like
you know what you're talking about. A
product manager isn't actually
delivering anything valuable and you
have some experience with big tech as
well, so you'll be able to speak to
that. What did you do with Audible and
Google? I I read that's not the way
you're supposed to do it. That's the
wrong way to do product management.
We're not being productled. We're not
doing this like a best-in-class company.
It's a lot. You know, I've heard some
folks estimate it at about a million
dollars a year for the average US
product team. And I think that as a PM,
people are kind of scared of that
because they might have a title. What is
that pie chart of Matt's business today?
My business breaks down when I go
shopping and spend all the money I made
on. She works for a veterinary tech
company. And she said something which I
thought was such a perfect encapsulation
of this, which was
Really quickly, I think a crazy stat is
that more than 50% of you listening are
not subscribed. If you can subscribe on
YouTube, follow on Apple or Spotify
podcasts, my commitment to you is that
we'll continue to make this content
better and better. And now on to today's
episode. Matt Lame, you've written
several successful product management
books, but you just wrote this one.
Indeed.
I mean the short answer is that we are
in precarious times as product people. I
think that for a long time I certainly
operated under the belief that if I did
what executives told me to do and if I
did things the right way and followed
the best practices then I'd be fine and
my team would be fine. And I think if
you look at, you know, even the last
week, the news coming in about layoffs
across many product
companies, it's just not true anymore. I
think the reality of this moment is that
product teams need to be able to speak
the language of the business, need to be
able to understand and articulate why
the business has made an investment in
this team and why that investment is
worthwhile. So, I wrote this book in the
hopes of taking that conversation, which
I think can be a really intimidating and
overwhelming conversation for working
product teams, and really trying to make
it accessible and just not easy cuz it's
never easy, but make it a little bit
more approachable for folks who might
not be accustomed to having to
understand and articulate business
impact.
And I think this is particularly common
outside of the PM roles that aren't
glamorized, right? Everybody's
glamorizing the PM roles at Google and
Meta and maybe those PMs are impact
driven or used to thinking about impact.
But I talk to PMs every day and I'd say
a larger percentage of PMs are in
traditional industries, maybe banking or
automotive or finance where the way
product management is practiced, they
don't necessarily have to think this
way. You know, it's funny. I think in a
lot of ways understanding the actual
business model of your actual company is
so key to understanding what impact
means in your own context. One of the
challenges I think about the way that
we've glamorized and celebrated these
big tech companies is that their
business model, their commercial
circumstances, as you pointed out, are
really different from those of most
companies, right? Most companies aren't
sitting on a massive pile of venture
capital or aren't in a situation where
they have a mature digital business
which is essentially printing money for
them. The commercial pressures that most
product teams are facing are much more
real, much more immediate, much higher
stakes than those of the companies from
which many of our best practices have
emerged. So, one of the challenges I see
is for product managers who've only read
about and heard about best practices
from the same three Silicon Valley
companies, when somebody at their
company says, "Yeah, yeah, yeah, that's
great. I love your best practices, but
we need to do this right now because the
company's in trouble." They go, "I read
that's not the way you're supposed to do
it. That's the wrong way to do product
management. We're not being productled.
We're not doing this like a
best-in-class company." And it's like
yeah, you're in a completely different
commercial setting from those companies.
Like you are going to face commercial
pressures that like the five most
successful companies in the world are
shockingly not facing in exactly the
same way. So I I think slash hope that
as we get more stories out into the
world from folks who are not necessarily
representing again the five ostensibly
most successful companies in the world
that folks will have more stories they
can look to and say all right you know I
work for a business there are
compromises that need to be made there
are trade-offs that need to be made the
way I work won't look exactly like the
way I've been told that the best
companies work, but that's okay. I think
that's a really important message. And
so today, I want to do a review from the
author. Okay. Something that probably
you can't get anywhere else, but Matt
reviewing his own book. And Matt has
even brought some slides. So, you want
to take us through those?
Okay. Welcome to my book review slides.
I tried to match the color scheme of
your podcast as best I could. give you a
little a little remix just for the fans
here. Um, so yeah, you're going to talk
about me. This is me. This is my fancy
slide. I've worked with some companies.
You know, again, there's always a
tendency to put the most impressive
names first, but I always tell people
that so much of the most interesting
work I've done is with companies that
don't necessarily wind up on a banner
slide like this.
books. Um, the more I talk about stuff,
the more my agile book goes farther
behind the other ones because I never
really want to talk about agile ever
again. One of the most interesting
things is you were head of consumer
product at Bit.ly. I was.
What was that like? Gosh, that was
fascinating. I learned so much. I mean,
that was really my first product role at
a startup in New York City 15 years ago.
I learned so much. I am so eternally
grateful to the patience and grace that
my colleagues there showed me. We had an
incredible team. You know, I think we
were struggling to figure out what the
identity of Bitly as a consumer product
was. And my time there ended with most
of my team going to the enterprise side
because that was where we were making
our money. And that's how Bitly has
continued to be a successful business to
this day. So, I think my time there
really taught me about how the coolest
and most interesting work to do is not
always the most impactful work. And at
the end of the day, if you want the
business to live to fight another day,
it's about really committing to the
business model that's working and
putting your resources against that
business model accordingly.
Fascinating. And you have some
experience with big tech as well, so
you'll be able to speak to that. What
did you do with Audible and Google? Um,
Audible, I did some training on
storytelling, data storytelling, which
was really fun. Spotify, I worked
primarily with their marketing team,
actually, which was really interesting.
Um, helping them do some research and
understand the different ways that
people consume music and audio. I was
very lucky when I was living in the
states to have a business partner named
Trisha Wong who is an incredible
ethnographic researcher who taught me
how to do that kind of work which you
know I talk about it a little bit in
product management in practice but I
think product managers are not innately
good at research unless they have a
little bit of practice. So I was very
lucky to be trained up by somebody
really good before I did that work for
Spotify.
I find that
uh research it's not something that's
unlearnable. It's just something you
need to be trained in. Absolutely. And I
think people underestimate how
uncomfortable it is. You know, when
you're used to working with stakeholders
all day, you're trying to get that
affirmative commitment. You're trying to
create clarity. You want to sound smart
and like you know what you're talking
about. When you're doing user research,
you don't want to sound too smart. You
don't want to sound too knowledgeable.
You don't want to go in there and tell
people exactly what your product does
and how it does it and why it's so
great. So I think that mindset shift is
really challenging for folks who haven't
had a chance to practice it a few times.
Awesome. So why do we care about being
impact first? We care about being impact
first because the business expects some
kind of return on the investment it has
made in every product team. Product
teams are not cheap from an operational
standpoint, right? If you have an
expensive product manager, a few
expensive developers, an expensive
designer, plus the cost of coordinating
that team, onboarding that team, it it's
it's a lot. You know, I've heard some
folks estimate it at about a million
dollars a year for the average US
product team. Your team is there for a
reason. At some point, somebody is going
to look at the cost of your team and
say, "Is this team delivering the return
we expect from them?" And if you don't
know what that return is, if you cannot
proactively manage the conversation of
here is why our team's work is important
to the business, then you run the risk
that somebody's going to look at your
team as a line item on a spreadsheet,
say, "Why are we spending a million
dollars on this?" And nobody in the room
is going to have a good answer. Hey, let
me take a quick break to talk about
something that's completely changed my
product management workflow. Linear. As
a PM, I was drowning in tools. One for
planning, another for issue tracking,
road maps, and sheets, and jumping
between Slack, Intercom, and app reviews
just to piece together customer
feedback. Sound familiar? I was spending
more time keeping systems in sync than
actually building product. Every time
development kicked off, my carefully
crafted plans would immediately need
updating. I was the human API between
all our teams, constantly chasing
updates and translating between tools.
That's why I love Linear. I can capture
customer feedback, shape product ideas
collaboratively, quarterback
crossunctional teams, and monitor
development progress in one place. It
cuts through the maze of disconnected
systems that were complicating my life.
Product teams at OpenAI, Verscell, Rex,
and Cash App all use linear. If you're
tired of spending your days keeping
different tools and teams in sync, check
out Linear at
linear.app/partners/
akash. That's
linear.app/partners/ aos. Today's
episode is brought to you by Miro. Let
me ask you something. How many tools are
you juggling just to get a single
project across the finish line? One for
brainstorming, another for planning,
something else for tracking tickets.
That's where Miro comes in. It becomes
an all-in-one collaboration workspace.
Whether you're consolidating user
research from several interviews,
developing and synthesizing product
briefs or a wireframe or project
managing development, Miro brings
everyone into the same space. It's fast,
intuitive, and fully loaded with
features like project templates, two-way
Jiraync, and integration with software
like draw.io and plant UML. Miro's AI
features can be used to synthesize
elements in a board to develop a
readyto-review product requirements
document in seconds. If you're tired of
tab overload and scattered workflows,
try Muriro. Head to miro.com and see why
over 90 million users choose Miro to
guide from idea to outcome. I think this
ROI is really really important in the
context of the environment you just
mentioned at the beginning where CFOs
are examining the R&D budget. They're
saying what is the ROI on this? They're
looking at okay six engineers each
engineer has a total compensation of
150k let's say fully loaded for the
company that's 200k. We got six
engineers that's $1.2 million. We got a
designer and a PM that's $1.6 million.
If we're spending $1.6 6 million. Are we
really getting $1.6 million in profit
back? Probably. A lot of product teams
can't answer that question. Absolutely.
And I think it gets even more
complicated because what the business
expects from every team is not the same,
right? You might have a team that's
working on innovation where what's
expected of them is explicitly not to
return money within the existing
business model but to pursue and
validate new business models and new
ways of making money. You might have a
team that's responsible for growing the
user base or expanding into new markets
because those are specific promises that
have been made to investors or
shareholders. So I think even the the
notion of a simple revenue-based
ROI undersells the specificity and
contextual complexity of this question.
Teams are there for a reason, but that
reason isn't always the same and it's
always risky to make assumptions about
what the business expects of your team
rather than again proactively navigating
and managing that conversation.
So where do we go from here? How do we
take this to our day-to-day work? Yeah,
that's the big question because it is
very easy to lose sight of impact as we
go about our day-to-day
work. So when I started writing impact
first product teams, I I had a
conversation with a friend of mine who's
a a really talented product manager I
worked with at Mailchimp and I was kind
of fumbling my way through explaining
the concept of the book. you know, it's
about how product teams can put business
impact at the heart of their work. And
it's not really about the stuff that
most other product books are about. That
stuff is kind of like, you know, the the
objectives and the strategy. That
stuff's all in there, but this is kind
of like cutting through that and getting
right from the impact to the day-to-day
stuff. And she said, "Oh, okay. I think
I get it. Most writing about product
management is about the middle. It's
about kind of these steps we take to
cascade and
structure every step from our goals to
the work we do. But what you're doing is
kind of drawing a straight line between
business impact and like
vibes. And I I kind of loved that
framing because it's true different
companies approach the middle in
different ways. is. And there are lots
of different really great books and
frameworks and ideas for approaching the
middle, for thinking about initiatives
and bets and strategy and outcomes and
objectives. But at the end of the day,
regardless of how your company
structures the middle, it is still your
job as a member of a product team to be
able to draw a straight line between the
work you're doing, the decisions you're
making, and the impact of that work and
those decisions. So my hope with this
book was that, you know, when people
come to me and they're like, "Are, you
know, we're doing OKRs, can we still do
this? We have bets. Can we still do
this? We have objectives. Does this
still apply to us?" The answer is yes.
It applies to every product team
because, as I say in the book, it's just
too risky to assume that every step in
the middle cascades perfectly back to
impact. you are much better off making
that connection as directly as you
possibly can.
Absolutely. And I think one thing that's
important here is the terminology.
You're talking about product teams.
You're not saying product managers. It's
incumbent on the product manager
probably to drive this activity, but
it's also incumbent upon the designers
and engineers to understand this, to
question this, to help the PM if they
are focusing on stuff that might not
have the ROI so that the whole team has
a positive ROI. Yeah, I'm really glad
you brought that up because at the end
of the day, it is the product team that
is the unit that delivers value, right?
a product manager isn't actually
delivering anything valuable themsel. It
always uh strikes me a bit curious when
you have functional goals that are
matrixed or in any way in tension with
crossf functional team goals cuz like
it's the team that's doing the work. The
team is delivering the software that
creates the value that delivers the
impact for the business. So I I feel
like I've wasted a lot of time in my
career getting pulled into conversations
about where exactly does the
responsibility begin and end between a
designer and a developer and a
programmer and if we have a product
owner and a product manager and a scrum
master and a delivery manager and a UX
designer and a visual designer and at
the end of the day I think and hope that
having specific impact level
goals unites those different functions.
and makes it clear that they have to
work together not just within a crossf
functional product team but with other
functions beyond that team if they want
to have a major impact for the business
at large
100%. So where does great product work
start? That is a great question. Great
product work starts by understanding
what success specifically means to the
business at large. So again, I think
we've been in this conversation about,
you know, should product managers be
responsible for profit and loss? Should
product managers and product teams have
revenue
targets? And again, to me, the answer
really depends on what that next
existential milestone is for the
business. If the business has quarterly
revenue projections they need to make,
then yeah, you should be able to speak
to how your work impacts those revenue
targets. If you're a startup that's
trying to raise the next round, it can
get a little bit trickier, right?
Because sometimes you're raising around
based on growth. Sometimes you actually
want to be reinvesting all that money.
You don't want to be focused on
short-term monetization. You want to be
focused on a long-term growth strategy.
And I found that in many cases when
product teams aren't clear on how the
business is measuring and thinking about
success, it is very very hard for them
to have the focus and clarity they need
to do good work. And I think that one
personal lesson for me here was it's
also worth
um peering above your immediate
management chain. So to give you a
really concrete example, when I was at a
firm, my manager and my skip level, they
were okay with us driving top of the
funnel metrics, monthly active users,
app downloads, and for them, if we were
driving those and exceeding the goals we
set for them, it was success.
Interestingly, when you went up one
final level to the CEO and the board
though, they are saying, "So what? You
drove all these monthly active users. So
what what does this mean for revenue?
And so just having your current boss or
your boss's boss be happy isn't always
the right aperture and you might have to
peer even further up. Well, this is
exactly why I think starting at the
business at large level is the best
place to start because as you said
there's risk that if you're working
towards these intermediate levels of
goals you know in a lot of cases I see
it being usage goals versus impact goals
right so you might say well our goal is
to have people use this feature but if
that feature isn't monetized effectively
if that feature isn't something that the
company really cares about then you can
have all the usage you want. But again,
the business is not actually getting
much of a return out of this team unless
there has been an explicit decision that
the usage of this feature is so
strategically important to the business
that we're going to measure its success
in different terms.
Yep. And even if they do, I think
sometimes you just want to you want to
think ahead. You want to be skeptical of
that.
Maybe even present to them, hey, we hit
our usage goals, but this only drove
this much revenue so that they're not
the ones bringing it up, but actually
you. Exactly. And I think even
estimating it up front, saying, "Look,
based on the way that we monetize our
features, if we hit this usage goal,
this is the amount of revenue we think
it would bring in for the business. And
if that number is substantially smaller
than the operating cost of the team
itself, then that's a conversation you
really want to get out ahead of. And I
think that as a PM, people are kind of
scared of that because they might have a
title. I am PM for the consumer app. But
I'm saying that the consumer app team
won't have a high ROI. But I actually
think this is the job of a PM. That's
why they hired you in the first place is
you are getting into the details after
they had given you some highlevel
strategy. And if you are realizing as
you get into the details that the ROI
isn't there, it's better for you to
voice that up so that they can reput you
into an area where there will be that
ROI. And I think if you speak up, you're
actually less likely to be targeted or
fired or laid off and instead be, oh,
he's a reliable guy who we can count on
to drive ROI. Well, it's funny because I
think a lot of people get freaked out
when they start talking about business
impact and suddenly like the CFO has
really strong opinions about the work
that they're doing and wants to talk to
them and you know the executive
committee isn't sure about their targets
and wants to work with them on
revisiting them. But you are better off
being the architect of your own scrutiny
than you are being scrutinized when you
are not in the room to participate
actively in that conversation.
So what is the scenario that you often
see where um people think things are
going well but maybe they
aren't? Yeah. So there's one specific
scenario I'm thinking of where I was
working with a startup that had a a very
small product team. They had raised a
seed round. They were looking at a
bright and exciting future. And you know
I asked the product team like how are we
doing? How are things looking? and they
said, "Oh, we're doing we're doing
great. It's amazing. User growth and
revenue are both going up. We're getting
money and we're getting
users." And know that's good in a sense,
but when I looked at the actual features
they were
building, I was really worried because
it seemed like they were kind of
building for two different futures,
right? They were building for their the
kind of the path they were on which was
like
B2B selling into enterprises, big
contracts, a fair amount of handholding
and manual work. But they were also
building this kind of big BTOC growth
play future where they had taken their
core technology and made it open to
content creators all across the world in
a kind of self-serve
model. This this worried me a little. So
I I went to their founder and said, "I'm
concerned cuz I see these two different
scenarios playing out, and I'm worried
that we're splitting the difference in a
way that means we will achieve neither
of these scenarios. So what's what does
success really mean in this moment? What
are we working towards? What is that
next existential milestone for the
business?" She really smart founder, she
said, "The next milestone is raising
that next round of funding." And I know
some people who are going to be able to
answer that question better than I can,
which is our investors. Let's get them
on the phone and just ask them directly,
what do you need to see from us to
consider us a further investable
business? So, we got on a call with
their investors and we said, you know,
we see these kind of two futures playing
out. What would you need to invest in us
further in either scenario? And two very
different scenarios emerged.
One of them, if we wanted to raise a big
round as a growth business with BTOC
potential, we'd need to see 10,000
monthly active content creators by the
end of the year. So like we need to see
10,000 people regularly creating on this
platform. Sounds good. Now, if we choose
to go the other path, we need to see
about $50,000 of monthly recurring
revenue if we want to raise a smaller
round as a sustainable B2B business. So
if we want to be on that path to
profitability. So I think what's really
important here was that we pushed to get
these as specific as possible. Not just
we need to see a bunch of growth or a
bunch of revenue because you know I
think teams will always look at what
they're doing and kind of be like this
seems good is this good enough? If you
don't have that clarity upfront, it's so
tempting to fall into that kind of
vanity metrics trap of saying, "Well,
the numbers are going up, how do we tell
a story that makes this sound good?" And
if that story is different from the
story the investors are telling, then
none of it matters. So, I brought this
to the product team. They took one look
at it and said, "Yeah, there is no way
we're going to have 10,000 monthly
active content creators. Like, this is
not going to happen. It's just not
happening."
But what that meant was that they could
actually focus on hitting that $50,000
monthly recurring revenue goal. So the
thing that was maybe most interesting to
me was a lot of folks on the team and
again this was a small team but the
focus really shifted away from feature
delivery towards like how do we maximize
the value of our contracts? How do we
sell in more to the folks who already
believe in our product? How do we find a
few really high value folks? How do we
make sure that people working on product
aren't just building the next thing they
think is cool, but working really
closely with our customers to actually
understand what they need and how we can
help them address those needs. So, one
of the many lessons I took away from
this story is that having those specific
impact level goals actually positions us
better to work with our customers. It
makes us more customer- ccentric, not
less customer centric. Because if we
know how much money we need to make,
then we can start to say which of our
customers are going to give us that
money and what's going to be valuable
enough for them to make that happen.
So, I want to steal the other side for a
second here. Yeah. Um, just on Monday, I
was talking to a PM. He runs the
experimentation platform at his company.
So he's not actually going to deploy any
experiments or any userfacing features.
All he's going to do is make
improvements to the experimentation
culture at the company. How can he
actually drive the bottom line?
This is a great question and a lot of
folks from these kind of intermediate
and supporting and operational teams
come to me and say this is nice but how
do we measure the impact of our work?
And I was at Mind the Product a couple
weeks ago, which is always a treat. And
my friend Emily Tate gave a really great
talk about that exact topic. How do you
measure impact when you're a platform
team? She works for a veterinary tech
company. And she said something which I
thought was such a perfect encapsulation
of this, which was software doesn't
vaccinate pets. In other words, if you
are building something that is used by
internal teams, you're probably not
going to own the metric, but you should
be able to speak to how your work is
going to enhance the metric. So, if
you're working on a team that's building
experimentation culture, what are the
teams you're supporting? What are the
impacts that they're going to be able to
make based on your support? I often tell
people on these teams, this is a chance
for you to switch your posture from that
of a ticket taker to that of an actual
partner with these teams because when
they come to you and say, do this, do
that, you can say, cool, what's the
impact you're working towards and how
will our support either help you deliver
more impact or deliver impact more
quickly? And if you can have those
conversations, then you're in a position
not only to have a measurable,
appreciable effect on impact, but also
to build that culture of impact
throughout the organization through the
teams you're working with.
I once worked with a really really good
platform PM. We'll take another affirm
example. He was leading our payments
platform and lots of teams would come
into him with requests. my team, the
growth team also came to him with some
requests. And what I thought was awesome
is he would he would have these meetings
with us where he'd say, "Yeah, explain
the request in total detail." And he'd
have his product analyst with him and
then he'd have the product analyst work
with our product analyst to estimate
what is going to be the impact down the
line if they build this for us and then
we build the thing on top of that. And
so he could really go back and compare
amongst all the businesses. This is what
the second order impact of what we're
going to do will be. And I think that
that's the type of mentality you want to
have. Today's episode is brought to you
by Amplitude. Building great digital
products is hard. You know that better
than anyone. Getting teams aligned,
measuring what matters, and scaling your
product strategy isn't easy. But what if
you had a clear framework to guide your
next steps? That's exactly what
Amplitude built. They studied the best
product teams to understand what really
drives impact and turn those insights
into the digital experience maturity
assessment. In 2 minutes, you'll be able
to see where your team stands and what
you can improve to build better products
faster. Click the link in the caption to
take the free assessment and get a clear
path to product growth. Absolutely. I
think that again that mentality where
you're focused on not how do we break
down goals until each team owns a metric
with zero overlap which is not how the
real world works but rather how do we
work together so that we can maximize
our contribution to the business at
large that's when really great work
happens
so what is the question people should be
asking themselves
yeah so the question which is one of the
six powerful questions in the book is
what are the measurable conditions that
must be met for our business to be

The thing that surprised me the most

the happiest product managers.
I did not expect this because I figured
